I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
to the Republic of Kiribati for the additional financing of the Road Rehabilitation Project.1 
 
2.  The  proposed  additional  financing  will  facilitate  the  rehabilitation  of  important  road 
network links by adding 7.8 kilometers (km) of paved roads and 0.5 km of unpaved roads to 
cover additional geographic areas in Betio and Bairiki linked to the current project, and assisting 
with expenditures to be incurred in completing the civil works. The additional scope will result in 
the overall project rehabilitating 37.5 km of paved roads and 8.5 km of unpaved feeder roads on 
South Tarawa.2 The additional road sections will complement the current project by ensuring 
consistent road quality throughout the entire South Tarawa road network. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Background. Kiribati is a small, remote country consisting of 33 of dispersed islands 
over 3.5 million square km of ocean. Tarawa, the capital of Kiribati, has a population of 56,300 
(55% of the total country population) and an average population density of 4,000 persons per 
square km.3 The communities on this island are linked to each other, and the international 
airport, by a single main paved road and three causeways that run from east to west. Urban 
development along the main road corridor, particularly in the far west in the main urban center 
of Betio, provides opportunities for cash employment and access to essential social services. 
 
4.  Current project. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved a project ADF loan on 
20 December 2010 in the amount of SDR7,621,000 ($12 million) for the Road Rehabilitation 
Project. In 2015, ADB provided additional financing in the form of an ADF grant in the amount of 
$2.4 million. The current project (i.e., the original project and the first additional financing) 
sought to significantly improve people’s lives by rehabilitating the South Tarawa road network, 
which in 2010 was acknowledged to have served its economic life. The road network serves the 
habitable part of the atoll, which is generally no more than 100 meters wide, with most of the 
population living, working, or studying in buildings that line both sides of the road. 
 
5.  There is strong collaboration between the cofinanciers and the government to deliver the 
project, with project cofinancing at $66.16 million inclusive of ADB’s share. The current project 
has  received  $26.97  million  of  cofinancing  from  the  World  Bank,  $15.21  million  from  the 
Government of Australia through the Pacific Region Infrastructure Facility, and $3.65 million 
from the Government of Australia through the Australia–Pacific Islands Partnership Trust Fund.4 
The government’s contribution has increased from $1.05 million in 2010 to $5.93 million in 2015.

6.  The current project is in line with the development objectives set out in the Kiribati 
Development  Plan,  2016–2019,  which  seeks  to  (i)  achieve  economic  growth  and  poverty 
reduction;  and  (ii)  create  a  sustainable  environment,  and  sustainable  governance  and 
infrastructure.5 The additional financing is consistent with ADB’s country operations business 
plan, 2017–2019 for Kiribati; ADB’s Pacific Approach, 2016–2020, which serves as the country 
partnership strategy; and ADB’s Midterm Review of Strategy 2020.6 The current project also 
supports the government’s efforts in the draft Transport Sector Development Plan 2016 to (i) 
serve mobility and accessibility needs; and (ii) provide reliable, safe, and economically efficient 
transport as priorities for improving economic development.7 South Tarawa has 41.6 km of 
paved roads and approximately 40 km of unpaved roads that support access to most areas in 
Betio, Bairiki, Bikenibeu, and Buota. Prior to the commencement of the project, inadequate 
routine road and drainage maintenance, prolonged wet weather, and heavy traffic volumes 
contributed to the rapid deterioration of the road network in South Tarawa. 
 
7.  The first additional financing, approved in 2015 (footnote 2), was necessary to help meet 
the financing gap identified with the civil works contract due to (i) underestimated base costs at 
the design stage, (ii) implementation delays that further introduced material escalation costs, (iii) 
exchange rate fluctuations effects, and (iv) increased transport costs.8 The government and the 
contractor agreed on overall costs for the current work scope totaling A$59 million inclusive of 
all  claims,  variations,  currency  fluctuations,  and  extensions.  The  request  for  the  second 
additional financing is to scale up the road network links by constructing an additional 7.8 km of 
paved main roads and 0.5 km of unpaved feeder roads to cover additional geographic areas in 
Betio and Bairiki that will be linked to the current project. 
 
8.  Current project performance. Progress on project implementation since the civil works 
contractor mobilized in July 2013, has advanced satisfactorily despite the initial procurement 
delays. As of October 2016, physical progress is at 96% with 97% elapsed time. As of the third 
quarter of 2016, the current project was classified as performing well. The following aspects 
have been assessed:  
(i)  Delivery of expected outputs. 
(a)  Output  1. Coastal protection works; 35.7 km of pavements with road 
safety features, including speed bumps, street lighting, and road signage; 
and  more  than  50  km  of  footpaths  are  complete.  Extreme  weather 
damaged the Betio causeway rock armor, resulting in deletion of the 
causeway pavement works.9 The road sector reforms are progressing 
well with the completion of the road safety action plan and the preparation 
of draft traffic legislation.

mitigated  the  risks  identified  during  processing  and  implementation.  Regular 
coordination meetings with the Public Utilities Board and project stakeholders will 
continue to take place to monitor and address any implementation risks. 
(v)  On track rating. The project is rated on track and has performed consistently 
well since November 2014. 
 
9.  Proposed additional scope. This second proposal for additional financing is to scale up 
the road network links by rehabilitating an additional 7.8 km of paved main roads and 0.5 km of 
unpaved feeder roads to cover the additional geographic areas in Betio and Bairiki that will be 
linked to the current project. The additional scope and associated costs is considered necessary 
to ensure that the project development objectives are met. The provision of additional financing 
would also enable the existing civil works contractor to undertake the remaining works in a 
timely and cost-effective manner, as the time and cost to mobilize a new contractor in Kiribati 
are significant. 
 
10.  The  road  sections  in  Betio  and  Bairiki  road  sections,  proposed  for  the  additional 
financing,  were  in  good  condition  at  the  project  scoping  stage  in  2010.  Since  then,  poor 
drainage, inadequate road maintenance, and extreme wet weather during 2015 and early 2016 
have  caused  these  road  sections  to  deteriorate  to  very  poor  condition.  The  government, 
therefore, decided to improve these road sections to enhance access to employment, markets, 
and services. 
 
 
                                                
10 The cofinanciers entered into a Memorandum of Understanding dated 5 March 2012, which provides guidance on 
the cofinanciers cooperation, coordination and sharing of information, particularly on the review of procurement 
processes, as well as safeguard requirements to ensure mutual agreement on project-related matters.

4 
11.  Retroactive financing. In June 2016, Cabinet approved the MPWU submission for the 
additional work and authorized the use of its own funds as bridge financing to cover costs until 
additional financing from a donor was confirmed. Following Cabinet’s decision, the Ministry of 
Finance and Economic Development requested ADB that $9 million of the Asian Development 
Fund (ADF) grant resources be brought forward from 2017–2018 to 2016 to provide additional 
financing for the rehabilitation of the damaged road sections in Betio and Bairiki. As the current 
project implementation was near completion, the government authorized the additional works 
using its own funds, before ADB could confirm the ability to bring forward the ADF resources. 
The government decision was made on the consideration that a delayed instruction to the 
contractor would have resulted in demobilization and a lack of in-country resources capable of 
constructing the important road network links. The government considers the additional road 
sections as high-priority roads as these are part of an essential road link that completes the 
road network around Betio and Bairiki. Works commenced in June 2016 and are expected to be 
fully completed by December 2016. Currently, government has disbursed about A$9.5 million of 
its own funds and expects further payments to be made for the remaining period. Subsequently, 
the government requested ADB to support the works with additional financing and requested 
approval for 100% retroactive financing. 
 
12.  With only 4% of the total 37.7 km of the original paved road and unpaved feeder road 
construction remaining, the volume of the additional work, is less than the ongoing contract, and 
its  accomplishment  will  ensure  the  overall  road  network  improvement  in  the  area.  The 
government, ADB, and cofinanciers are satisfied with the very high quality of the works and 
timeliness  of  implementation.  The  project  team  has  assessed  the  additional  sections  and 
confirms that rehabilitating these sections will achieve a consistent road quality throughout the 
entire South Tarawa road network completed under the current project. Further, the project 
team has assessed that the works are in full compliance with ADB procurement and safeguard 
guidelines and confirms that all current contract obligations remain. The works are ongoing and 
physical completion is expected by February 2017. For this reason, the team deems that the 
government's request for 100% retroactive financing can be supported.  
 
13.  Under  ADB’s  Cost  Sharing  and  Eligibility  of  Expenditures,  retroactive  financing  is 
permitted only if, among other factors, (i) it is specifically agreed by ADB and the recipient of 
grant financing in the grant agreement, and (ii) the amount to be retroactively financed does not 
exceed 20% of the grant.11 For the reason set out in paras. 11-12 above, the project team seeks 
a waiver from ADB’s Board on the 20% ceiling for retroactive financing and requests that the 
Board approve retroactive financing for 100% of the grant amount. 
 
14.  The current project is eligible for additional financing because (i) it remains technically 
feasible, economically viable, and financially sound; (ii) the government includes the investment 
as high priority in the Kiribati Development Plan (footnote 5); (iii) the additional financing is 
consistent with the project’s development objectives; and (iv) the overall project is consistent 
with ADB’s current country partnership strategy.12 The current project is rated as performing well. 
The safeguard categorization of the overall project remains unchanged. Additional financing of 
the current project is the most efficient way for ADB to maintain support for achieving the 
government’s objective in the road transport sector and is a suitable modality to make sure that 
(i) the overall project is successfully completed, (ii) the targets and indicators of the design and

B.  Impact and Outcome 
 
15.  The  impact  and  outcome  of  the  overall  project  will  not  change  with  the  additional 
financing. The impact will be an improvement in socioeconomic conditions for the people of 
South Tarawa. The outcome will be their access to a safe, sustainable, and well-maintained 
road network. 
 
C.  Outputs 
 
16.  Output 1 under the current project is that the government rehabilitates and upgrades 
29.7 km of paved main roads and 8.0 km of unpaved feeder roads of the road network on South 
Tarawa. The additional financing will expand the output 1 core indicators by constructing an 
additional 7.8 km of the main road in Betio and 0.5 km of selected feeder road, increasing the 
total rehabilitated and upgraded roads to 37.5 km of paved main roads and 8.5 km of unpaved 
feeder roads. Outputs 2 and 3 will remain unchanged. The design and monitoring framework 
has been revised (Appendix 1).

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Technical 
 
20.  The overall project has been assessed as technically viable, as demonstrated by the 
absence of any significant technical issues during the ongoing civil works. Project preparation 
included  a  comprehensive  road  safety  audit  of  all  of  South  Tarawa’s  roads,  and  the 
recommendations have informed the detailed engineering design.15 The project team confirms 
quality tests demonstrate the results met or exceeded specifications. The additional scope 
including road designs, safety features, pavement surfacing, and costs have been verified by 
the consulting engineer. The MPWU continues to monitor works and will issue instructions for 
remedial works, where required. The road runs near the edge of the lagoon for most of its length. 
A rise in sea level, extreme annual cycles of spring tides, and increased erosion are the most 
significant threats to its sustainability. Within the town areas of Betio and Bairiki, the additional 
scope will make use of existing drainage features (i.e., soak pits installed by the MPWU and 
drains installed during the previous Government of Japan-financed road improvements), with 
some works proposed to improve drainage. This will include cleaning out of existing drainage 
and, where practicable (in terms of site constraints and associated costs), landscape areas 
adjacent to the road to minimize roadway inundation. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
 
21.  The additional financing will fund the rehabilitation of missing links of the road network in 
high traffic areas. The preliminary economic analysis yielded an overall economic internal rate 
of return of 35.6% (from 40.3% in the original appraisal). The project remains economically 
viable.16 Such high returns reflect the significant transport cost savings from the 6,000 vehicles 
per day utilizing a much-improved road pavement. Consideration of unquantified road safety, 
health  benefits,  and  potential  decongestion  on  the main  road  in  Betio further bolsters the 
economic viability of the project. 
 
22.  The  project  roads  are  nonrevenue-earning  and  operated  by  the  MPWU,  a 
noncommercial  unit  that  receives  annual  allocations  for  operation  and  maintenance  of 
infrastructure  assets.  Recent  and  ongoing  public  sector  management  and  public  financial

report. Sydney.

management reforms are refocusing scarce resources toward funding of essential government 
functions  and  services,  including  infrastructure  operation  and  maintenance.  These  would, 
therefore, facilitate consistently adequate allocations to the MPWU for routine and periodic road 
maintenance. Government allocations are likely to be funded through the Revenue Equalization 
Reserve Fund, which should provide adequate operation and maintenance funding and support 
the sustainability of infrastructure assets. 
 
C.  Governance 
 
23.  Financial management. A public expenditure and financial accountability assessment, 
conducted in Kiribati in 2010, indicated that public financial management is weakened by (i) a 
lack  of  fiscal  discipline,  (ii)  non-retirement  of  advances,  (iii)  lack  of  financial  reconciliation 
between the executing agency—the Ministry of Finance and Economic Development (MFED)—
and the line ministries, (iv) lack of effective expenditure commitment controls, and (v) outdated 
legislation and regulations.17 Since then, development partners, including ADB, have assisted 
the government in designing and implementing the Kiribati Public Financial Management Plan, 
2011–2014.18 Improvements in public financial management have been noted by the project 
team, and the government plans to update the public expenditure and financial accountability 
assessment in 2017. 
 
24.  The financial management arrangements for the current project will continue for the 
additional financing. In February 2016, the World Bank carried out an implementation review 
that included assessing the financial management arrangements in the MFED and MPWU. The 
review was satisfactory, and ADB is comfortable with the World Bank's assessment. The MFED 
will continue to be responsible for the overall financial management of the project. A full-time 
qualified project accountant continues to handle all financial management activities. The project 
will  continue  to  use  direct  payment  and  reimbursement  disbursement  procedures,  and  all 
required audits will be carried out. Currently, no audited project financial statements are overdue, 
and  no  financial  management  issues  are  pending.  Of  the  four  audited  project  financial 
statements received, two were submitted early and two were submitted after the deadline. All 
audit reports were issued with unqualified opinions. 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
 
25.  The project will directly benefit the entire population of 56,300 (51.5% female and 48.5% 
male) of Tarawa, for whom the road is a vital shared communal asset (footnote 3). As the lone 
vehicular transport route on the atoll, the road provides access to vital infrastructure, social 
services, and economic opportunities. It sustains economic development, links communities, 
and is also the main thoroughfare for pedestrians. It will reduce roadside dust and improve air 
quality,  leaving  homes,  shops,  and  vehicles  cleaner;  and  reduce  damage  to  mechanical 
equipment. New footpaths will improve pedestrian safety and reduce reliance and spending on 
vehicle transport while encouraging nonmotorized transport. 
 
26.  The  current  project  diligently  carries  out  a  HIV/AIDS  information  and  education 
campaign for the contractor’s employees, subcontractors, consultants, and communities near 
the project site.

E.  Safeguards 
 
27.  Environment.  The  current  project  is  classified  category  B,  and  the  environmental 
management plan (EMP) prepared was updated to reflect ongoing impacts. The project is 
currently operating under the revised version 6 of the EMP approved in December 2015. The 
resulting  contractor’s  EMP  (revision  N)  was  accepted  in  August  2015.  The  main  potential 
impacts are (i) disturbance from dust arising from loading, unloading, and transportation of 
construction materials; (ii) noise; (iii) erosion and sedimentation from exposed surfaces during 
construction, which may affect the lagoon environment; (iv) risks from the use and disposal of 
hazardous materials such as used fuel and lubricants; and (v) greater risk of accidents from 
more vehicle movements. Detailed mitigation measures were incorporated in the project, as 
outlined  in  the  EMP.  An  international  environment  specialist  and  a  national  environment 
inspector were engaged during the construction phase to monitor compliance with the EMP and 
report to the Ministry of Environment, Land and Agricultural Development. The environmental 
classification for the additional financing is classified categorized C. 
 
28.  Involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples. The project is classified category 
B, and the resettlement plan has been updated to reflect anticipated impacts and provide 
guidelines for any unanticipated impacts. The additional financing is classified categorized C 
since no buildings are to be relocated and no economic crops are affected under the project. To 
the extent possible, the roads to be rehabilitated will follow the current road alignment, and any 
resettlement or compensation for economic loss will be undertaken in accordance with the 
updated resettlement plan. To date, compensation for loss of land and assets, mainly for the 
loss of fruit-bearing trees, has been paid to 97% of affected persons (327 in total). An escrow 
account has been established for the compensation of the remaining 13 affected persons as 
soon as the pending court cases are resolved and affected persons are traced. The project is 
classified category C for indigenous peoples, and no indigenous peoples, as defined under 
ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), are expected to be affected by the overall project. 
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
 
29.  No significant issues are expected to arise in implementing the overall project. Major 
risks  and  mitigating  measures  are  described  in  detail  in  the  risk  assessment  and  risk 
management plan.19 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES 
 
30.  The government and the MFED have assured ADB that implementation of the project 
shall conform to all applicable ADB policies, including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the project administration manual and grant document. 
 
31.  The government has agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are 
set forth in the grant agreement. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
32.  I am satisfied that the proposed grant would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve
